awd_titl_txt: Topics in Dynamical Systems: Attractors, Dimension, Lattice Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research deals with problems in the theory of smooth dynamical systems and their applications to mathematical and statistical physics as well as to areas in geometry. The main subject of study is hyperbolic dynamical systems, systems exhibiting "deterministic chaos"  phenomena;  that is, the appearance of irregular chaotic motions in purely deterministic dynamical systems. Many global properties of a dynamical system with sufficiently strong hyperbolic behavior can be deduced from studying the linearized approximation system along its orbits. The study of this phenomena originated in seminal works of Smale, Anosov and Sinai. Such systems possess a high level of unpredictability and exhibit strong chaotic behavior. In the proposal the PI considers the weakest (hence, most general) form of hyperbolicity known as non-uniform hyperbolicity. It was introduced and studied in earlier work of the PI and is based upon the theory of separation of close orbits over time, called Lyapunov exponents. The goal of the proposed research is to develop a set of analytic tools for the subject and to construct some natural invariant measures with rich statistical properties. 

There are several main topics in the proposal: 1) Thermodynamic formalism for non-uniformly hyperbolic dynamical systems -- that is to establish existence and uniqueness of equilibrium measures and study phase transitions for systems with nonzero Lyapunov exponents; 2) Sinai-Ruelle-Bowen (SRB) measures for non-uniformly hyperbolic systems -  that is to construct "physically natural" classes of invariant measures for dissipative systems with nonzero Lyapunov exponents; 3) Gibbs and equilibrium measures for non-uniformly hyperbolic systems constructed via a new approach that does not rely on symbolic representation of the system; 4) Essential coexistence of hyperbolic and non-hyperbolic behavior -- that is to complement the famous Kolmogorov-Arnold-Moser (KAM) theory by constructing particular examples of systems with coexistence of areas with nonzero Lyapunov exponents and areas with zero topological entropy.

por.por_cntn:
One of the fundamental discoveries in the theory of dynamical systems in the second part of the last century is the phenomenon known as deterministic chaos -- the appearance of "chaotic'' motions in purely deterministic dynamical systems. These motions "occupy" a significant part of the phase space of the system (if not the whole phase space) and are persistent if the system is slightly perturbed. The chaos theory goes back to the works of H. Poincare and is associated with such great names as D. Anosov, D. Ruelle, Ya. Sinai and S. Smale. 
The activities related to the project are among the main directions of research in the modern theory of dynamical systems and their applications to other areas of mathematics as well to natural sciences, engineering and beyond. Main outcomes of the project include: 1) an advancement of our knowledge of various mechanisms that can cause chaotic behavior; 2) introduction and study of invariants that can be used to characterize chaotic behavior; 3) constructions of new examples of dynamical systems with chaotic behavior; such systems (often called in applications "strange attractors") appear in numerous models in physics, chemistry, biology and engineering; 4) the development of some innovative techniques to study systems in which chaotic behavior coexists with sufficiently regular ("non-chaotic") one in a robust way; this means  that both types of behavior are easily observable and cannot be destroyed by small perturbations of the system; 5) development of dimension theory of "chaotic" fractal invariant sets asociated wiith dynamical systems.
The results of the project have opened up some new directions of research in the study of thermodynamics of chaotic systems, dimensions of "strange attractors" and some others.
The results of the project have been disseminated through talks given by the PI at some national and international conferences, workshops and other meetings as well as through expository articles and books. They were also used in training of graduate students and postdocs, teaching special topic courses on dynamical systems as well as giving mini-courses at various international mathematical schools.
